message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest infective endocarditis, and among the options, Enterococcus faecalis is the most common organism causing infective endocarditis in patients with normal heart valves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest infective endocarditis with the presence of petechial conjunctival hemorrhages, macular lesions on both palms, heart enlargement to the left side, and a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex of the heart. Among the options, Enterococcus faecalis is the most common organism that causes IE. Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Candida albicans infections are less likely to cause IE, while Streptococcus viridans infections are more common in patients with underlying dental problems which this patient does not report having.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with infective endocarditis, which is associated with bacterial infections. Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of infective endocarditis. None of the other options are commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest infective endocarditis, which is often caused by Streptococcus viridans or Enterococcus faecalis. The symmetric edema in both legs suggests heart failure due to valve damage caused by the infection. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is unlikely to be the cause and Candida albicans is not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest infective endocarditis. The organism most commonly associated with infective endocarditis is Streptococcus viridans, but in this case, the patient has clubbing, conjunctival hemorrhages, and symmetric edema in both legs, suggesting salmonella or enterococcus as the causative organism. Enterococcus faecalis is commonly associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of intermittent fever, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, exercise intolerance, and the presence of petechial conjunctival hemorrhages and macular lesions on both palms suggest infective endocarditis. Among the options, Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of infective endocarditis, especially in patients with underlying urinary tract infections or gastrointestinal tract diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs described suggest endocarditis, which commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans and Enterococcus faecalis. The patient also has petechial conjunctival hemorrhages and macular lesions on both palms, which is known as Janeway lesions, a classic finding in endocarditis. Among the options, Enterococcus faecalis is the most likely organism to be cultured from the patient’s blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including petechial hemorrhages and macular lesions on the palms, suggest endocarditis. Among the options, Enterococcus faecalis is the most common cause of endocarditis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause endocarditis, but it is rare. Streptococcus viridans can also cause endocarditis, but it usually affects people with damaged heart valves. Candida albicans can cause endocarditis, but it typically occurs in immunocompromised patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest infective endocarditis, which commonly involves Streptococcus viridans and Enterococcus faecalis. Enterococcus faecalis is more commonly associated with subacute presentations and is therefore the more likely cause in this patient. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of hospital-acquired infections, but does not commonly cause endocarditis. Candida albicans is more commonly associated with immunocompromised patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of petechial hemorrhages, macular lesions on both palms, symmetric edema in both legs, and a holosystolic murmur at the apex suggest infective endocarditis. Enterococcus faecalis is a common cause of infective endocarditis, especially in patients with underlying genitourinary tract abnormalities.
